title: WCAS POLI_SCI 240-0-20 Introduction to International Relations
class_attributes:
Social & Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

Registration for discussion section required

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This introduction to the study of International Relations (IR) examines the development of IR theory by placing it in historical context. It seeks to provide the student with both an introduction to IR theory, an overview of the history that inspired that theory, and a critical engagement with theory by juxtaposing it with the history that conditioned its development, and the history that we are living in the present.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. FAMILIARITY WITH IR THEORY.
2. FAMILIARITY WITH 20TH CENTURY DIPLOMATIC HESTORY.
3. CRITICAL DISTANCE RELATIVE TO IR THEORY.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Eric Hobsbawm, The Age of Extremes, 978-0679730057
and Tim Dunne et al., eds., International Relations Theories: Discipline and Diversity, 978-0199696017, THIRD EDITION
A course packet contains other readings.
